fields.summary: File comment layout partially obscured

fields.description: We're analysing the author field before we store it in the lucene index, but not analysing it before we search for it to retrieve reviews.  This field should not be analysed in the first place.
fields.summary: Crucible search doesn't deal properly with author user names containing punctuation

fields.description:
Currently, when reviewers are either removed or added, or the moderator is changed, a ReviewUpdatedEvent is fired. Our plugin needs to detect both added and removed participants, but we face the following problems:

# When a reviewer is added, a call to {{reviewService.getAllReviewers(event.getReviewId())}} will not contain the added reviewer.
# -When a reviewer is removed or the moderator changed to someone else, the ReviewUpdatedEvent does contain enough information to know who the removed participants were.- Moved to separate feature request: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6100
fields.summary: Allow plugins to detect changes to reviewers or moderator
Stopped repositories cause NPEs in crucible reviews

fields.description:
The reason why we need to manually add the reviewers is because - while creating a review through REST, Crucible is not defaulting the reviewers to the group defined in the permission scheme. For a manually created review, this defaulting happens. 
There is some gap in Crucible documentation, where the Add Review is not working the way it is documented. 
I tried
/rest-service/reviews-v1/{perma-id}/reviewers/{user1, user2}
I also tried creating the xml payload forthe post with reviewers/reviewer
fields.summary: addReviewers through REST does not work in Crucible

fields.description: Manually created review comment - sends notification email to revieweres, but the one created through REST does not
fields.summary: Notification email is not sent from Crucible to Reviewers when a general comment is added through REST

fields.description: when changing the layout to side-by-side diff in a review, the layout sometimes switches to a three column layout instead of a three column layout. This makes it hard to review code.
fields.summary: Side-by-side diff ends up splitting in a 3 column layout

fields.description:
The FE library that does the timelines can only handle a few timezones - "GMT", "UTC", "PST", "MST", "CST", "EST". Anything else makes it barf.

The library responsible is simile timeline.

To reproduce set the JVM timezone to another zone (e.g. CET) and try to view the timeline.
fields.summary: Timelines only work with a small set of timezones

fields.description: It would be very helpful to have some more functionality to ease navigation through comments in Crucible.  When a file has a lot of comments, it can be time consuming to navigate to the comments that have not been read yet.  It would be really helpful if the system could place you at the newest/unread comments in a file when you enter the file. Or, if there was a filter that could hide comments that have already been read.  One of the complaints I've received is that when a lot of comments are entered for a specific  line of code or throughout a file, the file becomes difficult to read.  Users have beeen closing reviews and opening new reviews to get around this problem.  If we could just hide or collapse the comments when we don't want to see them, that would take care of this problem.
fields.summary: Crucible enhancements to comments functionality

fields.description:
After selecting the changeset, adding two reviewers, and details, I clicked the button to start the review and got some error popup dialog (which disappeared before I could capture it). The review was eventually created, but there were duplicate reviewers displayed. 

This was happening in the previous version of Crucible. We thought upgrading would fix it.
fields.summary: Crucible creating double review entries

fields.description:
On atlaseye, trying to prune down a large review, but am unable to delete some files.

The review in question is 
https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3718
and try deleting Maven1BuildTask.java

I get a popup with 

"An error has occurred

You are running release FE3.0.0-M1 (49abfd906670 2011-11-08), please report your release number when reporting bugs. "
fields.summary: Cannot delete files from a review

fields.description: In older versions of Crucible we often allowed slightly non-standard patch formats and did best-effort processing on them.  We've changed our approach so that we now reject those patches, but it would be good if users had the option getting crucible to do best-effort parsing.
fields.summary: Allow optional lenient validation of uploaded patches
Review creator is unavailable from within ReviewCreatedEvent handler

fields.description: When upgrading from a very old version of FECRU to the more recent versions (in the case of one particular customer the upgrade was from 1.6.7 to 2.6.6), all existing review comments are wrapped in {preserve-old} tags so that any accidental markup in old comments isn't rendered.  In places where we use the plain text view of the comments, eg the {{Details}} section, the {preserve-old} tags aren't filtered out when they easily could be.
fields.summary: In some places pre-2.0 review comments always show the {preserve-old} tags

fields.description:
FishEye uses a nice side-by-side diff we're used to nowadays (IntelliJ, P4V, etc).
This was introduced in 2.2 as a result of ShipIt.
Crucible still has the "old" side-by-side diff.
Can Crucible also get the new side-by-side diff?
fields.summary: Integrate Fisheye's side-by-side diff viewer into Crucible

fields.description:
I would like crucible reporting to be opened up and hooked up to fisheye, so that some of these requirements can be accomplished:


# Number of reviews created, under review, closed along with age in a given sprint
# Files changed and number of changes – fisheye – something that we talked about to monitor files that change frequently and potentially review their design.
# User Story/Defect and metrics related to the review
## Number of reviewers
## Amount of time spent in review
## Number of iterations back and forth
fields.summary: Reporting

fields.description:
If you try to create a review in FishEye 2.7.7 and use the patch attached to this ticket, it'll fail with this message in the UI:
bq. Error adding patch: Unrecognised diff format. Expected diff hunk descriptor but found: +/*

I was able to reproduce this problem locally with the patch attached. Nothing is outputted in the logs, unfortunately.

However, this works like a charm in Crucible 2.3.6, so it's not a problem with the patch file.
fields.summary: Error adding patch: Unrecognised diff format. Expected diff hunk descriptor but found: +/*

fields.description:
On the [About Crucible|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE026/About+Crucible] page, this link is broken:

Visit the [Crucible Feature Tour|http://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/features/] to understand how Crucible can benefit you.
fields.summary: Feature Tour link broken

fields.description:
When creating a patch review and selecting the "Paste text from clipboard" option, the "upload" button that is used to upload a patch file is still visible. I want to click it to confirm the text, but I get a file upload error. 

The same problem exists in OnDemand - https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JST-5691
fields.summary: Crucible patch reviews - "Paste text from clipboard" option does not work.

fields.description:
As of FishEye and Crucible 2.7, it is not possible to delete an internal user and then synchronise them from crowd or ldap instance and retain their content (reviews, comments, committer mappings etc).

This was possible in 2.6, however this was the result of a bug in FishEye/Crucible that also led to security problems.

The correct method of doing this is to add the user to ldap/crowd and then sychronise FishEye/Crucible with the directory server, then change the Auth Type of the user from "built-in" to "crowd" or "LDAP". 

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/JIRA+and+Crowd+Authentication details the process of setting up crowd and ldap.
fields.summary: Deleted users migrated to ldap/crowd don't retain content

fields.description:
When a new user is synced for LDAP or Crowd (possibly also when auto-adding), it is automatically enabled for FishEye and Crucible.

This makes it possible that the users license limit is exceeded, meaning that all attempts to use FishEye and Crucible thereafter redirect to the user admin page (CRUC-5927)

We need to improve this, to not add users that would exceed the license limits and instead log messages saying we are not adding them.
fields.summary: LDAP/Crowd Users auto-synced and added as crucible users, exceeding licence limit
cs link macro shouldn't always require repo name

fields.description:
When i view side by side diff of the html file. it mixes up when i have line numbers on.
See attachment for details.
fields.summary: side by side diff view does mix up when having long line
UI improvements to the Edit classification admin screen

fields.description:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Configuring+Crucible#ConfiguringCrucible-SupplyingAdministrationPasswordandLicenseKey
Has a link to an outdated screenshot, and mentions that the Server ID is shown (it's not).
fields.summary: Outdated documentation re. first time installation

fields.description:
Currently, Crucible can't anchor patches which are not relative to the most recent revision in the repository.

If this kind of patch is added to a review, no useful UI msg is reported on why the anchoring failed.

Based on: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/18907/how-to-create-a-pre-push-review-with-mercurial
fields.summary: Better UI communication when DVCS patches are unsuccessfuly anchored

fields.description: If you create a very large review, then think better of it and delete it, your instance will still spend a long time trying to index the review -- see https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-3281
fields.summary: Deleting a review doesn't delete associated rows from cru_feindex_msg

fields.description: I don't have a way of reproducing this, but if you select a repository in the add content, browse changesets dialog, you then seem to see a different set of repositories for a similar substring
fields.summary: Autocomplete repository selection in add content, browse changesets dialog behaves inconsistently

fields.description: On AtlasEye (3.0.0-M1), if I am writing a long comment, sometimes someone else publishes their comment while I'm still writing mine. If I then try to publish my long comment, I get an error and my comment is lost completely.
fields.summary: Comment creation fails and loses comment text if another comment has been added after starting to write the comment

fields.description: When creating a patch from {{hg diff}}, Crucible doesn't anchor the diff to the repository correctly.  However, when creating the patch using the '--nodates' option, crucible successfully anchors the patch.  This should be fixed so that the --nodates option is not needed for anchoring.
fields.summary: Patch reviews from mercurial diffs don't anchor to their repository unless using --nodates argument for hg diff

fields.description:
When there are thousands of crucible users in the DB, review creation and editing can become slow.

This is because:

# The list of all users is unnecessarily loaded when the review page is rendered
# When getting all the candidate reviewers for a review which has a restricted set of reviewers, the list of all users is loaded, even though there is a faster way of checking that all the allowed reviewers are active users.

Note that review creation/editing in a project with no restriction on the allowed reviewers may still be slow even after this bug is fixed, when there are thousands of crucible users.
fields.summary: Crucible 'active users' list loaded unnecessarily, making review creation and editing slow

fields.description:
After a long period of inactivity, when a user tried to authenticate via OpenID to Crowd/CrowdID they got this attached error.  I can add the stacktrace here if you think it is valuable to have it inline. essentially it looks like the MySQL connection pool was possibly stale.

I attached the error page and our my.cnf file
fields.summary: Crowd failed with a JDBC Error: org.hibernate.TransactionException: JDBC begin failed

fields.description:
This option would be very handy when adding content to a review by changeset.

The list of changesets might be very long and a lot of scrolling and paging is needed to find the changesets that are not yet reviewed.
An additional filtering option "Not yet reviewed changesets" would really speed-up finding unreviewed changesets.

I could also imagine such a checkbox on the commit activity stream page of the user or project.

Also, in the activity stream of commits, a new option to "Add to review..." in the Options dropdown on the right, with a dialog then showing open reviews the user has created, instead of just "Create Review", would be very helpful.
fields.summary: Enable users to filter changesets by "Not yet added to a review"

fields.description:
A regression caused by the fix for [CRUC-5932|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-5932] makes side-by-side diffs in Crucible misaligned.

Anchored patch diffs are unaffected, but all other diffs exhibit this problem.
fields.summary: Side-by-Side Diffs in Crucible are misaligned.  Line number columns are very long

fields.description:
Firstly, let me say I'm sorry that this is a Heisenbug.

We have a Crucible integration that creates reviews for changesets from the past day.  Sometimes the reviews created by that integration will inexplicably transition from Review to Draft state.  When I check the history log for the review, there's no indication that the transition happened.  For example, here's the exported history log CSV for one such review: 

"Date","User","Action","Details","Entity ID","Old value","New value"
2011/11/03 10:34:46,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_CREATED",,,,
2011/11/03 10:34:46,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_FRX_ADDED",,347077,,"11259 "
2011/11/03 10:34:46,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_FRX_ADDED",,347078,,"10271 11258 "
2011/11/03 10:34:47,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_FRX_ADDED",,347079,,"11257 "
2011/11/03 10:34:47,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_FRX_ADDED",,347080,,"11256 "
2011/11/03 10:34:47,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_STATE_CHANGE",,,"Draft","Review"
2011/11/03 20:29:48,"dailyreviews","REVIEW_STATE_CHANGE",,,"Draft","Review"

You can see that the integration created a review, added a bunch of change sets to it, and then immediately transitioned it from Draft to Review state.  Later I noticed there was a review floating around that was in Draft state that shouldn't be, so I manually punched it back to Review.

Our integration dumps all of the HTTP communication it's doing with Crucible. Looking at that log, we can be pretty sure that Crucible thought that the review was in Review state when the integration was done with it.

Have you heard of a problem like this before?  Do you have any suggestions for what our integration could do differently to work around this weirdness?

Thanks,

Leif
fields.summary: Occasionally reviews created with the REST API will magically transition from Review to Draft state

fields.description:
In order to minimize administration overhead
I as a Crucible administrator
want to be able to use "Allowed Reviewers" when assigning permissions in a Crucible permission scheme.

I will know this is done when:
Given a FeCru instance with multiple Crucible projects
and each Crucible project has different "Allowed Reviewers"
When I assign "Allowed Reviewers" to a permission in a Permission Scheme (for example, the Create Review or View Review permission)
and login as a user with the "Allowed Reviewers" permission on a subset of the Crucible projects
Then I can only perform the action(s) associated with the permission assigned to "Allowed Reviewers" in projects in which I am an "Allowed Reviewer".

h3. Context

I am an administrator for an environment in which we have integrated multiple Atlassian products (JIRA+Greenhopper, Confluence, Fisheye/Crucible and Crowd).  We have more than 50 projects in this integrated environment and are continuing to add projects.  For each Crucible project we have groups that are assigned as "Allowed Reviewers" to the project.  

In the current implementation of Crucible Permission Schemes if I want to limit a permission (for example, Create Review or View Review) to the same group of people that are assigned as "Allowed Reviewers" I have to create a Permission Scheme per project and assign the project specific group to that permission.

By implementing the described functionality a Crucible administrator would be able to define a single Permission Scheme based on granting the permission to "Allowed Reviewers" and apply that one Permission Scheme to all of the projects.  This is because each permission is in the context of a Project and so the "Allowed Reviewers" for that project would have the permission in that context.

Note that for at least the "Create" and "View" permissions assigning the permission to "Reviewers" _does_not_ accomplish the same thing. It isn't clear what assigning "Reviewers" the "Create" permission accomplishes, since by definition there are no active "Reviewers" for a review that does not yet exist.  Assigning "Reviewers" the "View" permission appears to be redundant because if someone is participating in a review it would seem that by definition they can view it.
fields.summary: Allow assignment of permissions to "Allowed Reviewers" in Permission Schemes

fields.description: We experience a multitude of problems trying to get the correct change sets into reviews.  We think these problems would all be addressed by having the ability to add a change set to a review from anywhere in fisheye/crucible.  It is much easier for us to find the things we want to review via the standard source browser, commit graph, etc than it is using the interface presented for adding data from within the review.  Unfortunately, crucible seems to only support creating a new review for a changeset from locations like Jira issues, the source browser and the commit graph.  If the interface was extended with a "Add to review [ ]" option our workflow would get significantly more streamlined.  Thanks for reading this.

According to a Issue Description:

"..a way to grant entitlements to all Leads for things like Edit Review Details in their respective projects only. The reason is that sometimes the author and/or moderator leave the firm and we want an easy way for leads to go into Crucible and resolve these cases and manage this data.

What I'd like to be able to do is grant access to the role of Lead to Edit Review Details but as you point out it is impossible. What I believe I'm currently forced to do is have project specific permission schemes to grant access to Edit Review Details on a project by project basis (e.g., I want 123-Leads to have this for only their project and likewise for 345-Leads)

fields.description:
Hi, some of our teams do code review on components or an area of software that is tightly related, and at the same time the code is owned/architected/managed by a Subject Matter Expert who needs to sign off on reviews before the are moved to complete.  

Since there is no way in Crucible to mark a given reviewer as "required completed" before a review is closed, we can't simply add the SME as a reviewer, and we can't ask the SME to always be the creator of the review.

So, we ask that a feature be added to allow at least one reviewer to be marked as required completed before the review can be completed.  That way we can add the SME to the review, and they must approve/complete the review before it can be closed.  

Ideally though this would go a step further and allow the SME to actually gate the closure of the review somehow, maybe someone marked as "required complete" also gets an "approve check box or something?
fields.summary: how to require approval before completion

fields.description:
At present, when the licensed number of users is exceeded, everyone is redirected to the user admin page where a message saying "You have <n> more Crucible users than allowed by your licence" is displayed. Most users will not be authenticated as the administrator, and so will just see the administration login, with no explanation.

We need to make it far easier to understand what is happening -- users should be sent to a page which explains the problem, and includes a link to the user admin page.

We must also log explanatory messages.
fields.summary: Improve behaviour when licence limits are exceeded

Please see the images attached for reference.

fields.description:
These all exist on master:
!http://content.screencast.com/users/AdamAtlassian/folders/Jing/media/9f3342ac-8c04-40bb-a4c2-7f8aa3d616a2/2011-09-28_1727.png!


Suppose you have a changeset 1 in branch A, and a changeset 2 that is in both branches A and B (this is possible only on Git).

Create a review with these 2 changesets.

In Crucible, we show files from changeset 1 under the branch A heading.

For files from changeset 2, they may show up under either the branch A heading IF those files were also changed in changeset 1.  Otherwise, we show them under the branch B heading.



This is confusing - all the changes appear on branch A and that is obviously the branch being reviewed.  All changes should show up under the branch A heading.


Possible solution:  If all changes in a review are on a common branch, list them all under that branch name.
fields.summary: In Git, our separation of files by branch can be confusing

fields.description:
One of our users gets added to a lot of code reviews were he isn't actually the required reviewer, but rather an optional reviewer. The problem is that he has no easy way of telling, in his long queue of pending reviews, which ones he really needs to take action on.

He suggested that just as meetings in Outlook have required and optional attendees, crucible reviews should have required and optional reviewers, and these should be manipulable in useful ways by both the reviewers and reviewees. For example, a reviewer should be able to easily differentiate between his required and optional reviews, and a reviewee should be able to see easily when all required reviewers have finished, even when some optional reviewers haven't.
fields.summary: Mandatory and optional reviewers

fields.description:
[https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-3542]
(Version:3.0.0-M1 Build:692f8130e1af 2011-09-15) 

I'm unable to add files to that review. I'm trying to to click on the "Add content to this file" button (the blue '+' in rectangle) -> Then I try to click "Explore Repositories". The page goes gray, and the loading spinner is shown. After a few minutes nothing happens - the spinner is spinning, I can't cancel out and have to reload the page. I expected that after some time I'll be shown a file-tree browser and I will be able to add some files from bamboo-hg repository.

Is this a bug? Or am I improperly using atlaseye?
fields.summary: Unable to add files to review using "Explore Repositories" option

fields.description:
According to customer's description:
"I'd like to be able to label all files in my project as either "compliant" or "non compliant". It's a little bit like the "Favorite" label, but I'd like the label to be shared by all users, and I'd like to see it when I look at the list of all files in Source."

The use case:
"We are working on code that will be part of an FDA submission. All the
code needs to comply with our Software Development Plan. Since we have
a lot of legacy code, we are bringing it into compliance. Some of the
files are compliant, some are not, and some are somewhere inbetween.

Non-compliant can mean several things. For example, the file hasn't
been reviewed or the appropriate level of testing hasn't been
provided."
fields.summary: Labeling files

fields.description: In most Linux environments "alt + mouse drag" moves the current window and the event is never delivered to the application. This is the only way I know of selecting source code in Crucible, so I usually end up either memorising the contents or opening the same file in IDE in order to perform copy paste. Ideally there would either be an additional keyboard shortcut (e.g. alt + shift + mouse drag) or a toggle button in the UI for being able to select text. Toggle button might be better as it would be more discoverable.
fields.summary: Support alternative way for selecting text in source code

fields.description: On version 3.0.0-M1 Build:692f8130e1af 2011-09-15 if I click a source file on sidebar, it is opened. If I then try to use keyboard shortcuts (spacebar, page up, page down) to navigate in the file, it fails because the sidebar still has focus. Even clicking the source code does not help. Clicking on the white bar where previous/next change links are placed finally changed the focus to the source code.
fields.summary: Switch focus to source file when opening a file from the sidebar

fields.description: Happens on AtlasEye (Version:3.0.0-M1 Build:692f8130e1af 2011-09-15) and also affects keyboard shortcuts ("," and ".").
fields.summary: Go to previous/next element navigates should support moving between changes

fields.description:
Most actions, if they are even shown in the UI, end up throwing a NPE.

Product management have decided this is a feature we don't want to support anyway.

Remove all 'allow anon users' permissions from all but 'view review'
fields.summary: 'Allow anon users' permission is broken for all but 'view review' and should be removed.

fields.description:
Set the comment permission to allow all logged in users access via Admin > Permission Schemes
Access the review as a logged in user not part of the review you`ll notice that there isn't any option allow you to add a comment
fields.summary: Comment permissions don't work for 'all logged in users'

fields.description:
Wherever pagination is used in the Crucible UI for navigating through lists, there appears to be no way to jump to a specific page. This is very unwieldy with larger lists.

This is a significant user interface issue where users have to spend longer navigating through the upgraded version of crucible than they did in the version that we are upgrading from.

E.g. consider the Repositories page in the administration interface with 22 pages. There is no way to jump to page 20 or 21 as an example. This means clicking the right arrow 21 times just to get to a specific point in the view. This borders on unusable.
fields.summary: Administration repository list needs better pagination

{quote}
I know that ideally reviewer should not access the review until it has been sent for review but user can as there is no restriction in the tool.
